results.title: The Irish empire
results.creator_credit: Alan Gilsenan, David Roberts, Dearbhla Walsh, Ritchie Cogan, Cafe Productions (London), Hilton Cordell Productions and Little Bird (Dublin)
results.brief_description: Ireland is just a tiny country that has never sought domination, yet it has established Irishness and Irish power bases and communities from Chicago to Vladivistok, from Australia to Argentina. There is no physical empire, but an empire of imagination, a virtual empire, whose followers outnumber the native population in Ireland by over fifteen to one. From a home population of just 4 million, some 70 million people around the world call themselves Irish, or claim Irish descent. This is a thought-provoking exploration of how the Irish have so often triumphed over adversity and established themselves all over the world. It explores the past and present attitudes and ideas which have allowed the Irish people to spread across the world without loosing a sense of identity generations later. Narrated by Fiona Shaw.

results.title: The Invisible World
results.creator_credit: Alex Pomasanoff and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: If it were not for some extraordinary photographic techniques, sophisticated cameras and imaging devices, many events that the human eye cannot perceive - because these occurrences are too small, too large, too fast or beyond the spectrum of visible light - would go unnoticed. This film captures such events that would otherwise escape our inspection.

results.title: The Invisible children (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Christopher Brough, Rift Fournier and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Presents the Kids on the Block, a unique group of puppets in that one is deaf, one blind and another in a wheelchair. They tour the country encouraging non-disabled children to ask and learn about their handicapped peers and to see the world through different eyes. Stars Gary Burghoff (from TV’s MASH) and was made during an actual classroom presentation. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Impossible takes a little longer
results.creator_credit: Anne Henderson, Barbara Janes, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Impossible Takes a Little Longer documents the work and personal lives of five physically disabled women. It shows how they are coping with the problems they share with all women, the problems they share with other disabled women and those unique to their particular circumstances. The film affirms that disabled women can lead full and productive lives as workers, as mothers and as valued community members. It informs both disabled women and the able-bodied about the possibilities of adaptations in the workplace, the use of technological aids and the need for support systems if disabled women are to have satisfying and productive lives. The Impossible Takes a Little Longer undermines the stereotypes and prejudices that further hinder a large segment of our population.

results.title: The Invention of the adolescent
results.creator_credit: Patricia Watson, Cecily Burwash, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From the past, when distinctions between childhood and adulthood were not as finely drawn as they are today, this film traces the development of the adolescent and shows some of the real problems of this age. It notes that it was the defense of the young, the protection afforded by reformers and educators, that created the generation gap so evident today in Western society. What adolescents gained and lost from changing attitudes towards them is clearly illustrated in the film. (Awards: New York; La Plata; Tehran)

results.title: Watch your step
results.creator_credit: Basic Films and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Industrial Safety”
An accident prevention film with special reference to the building industry. This film re-creates, from actual records, some of the more common accidents and points out the ways in which they could have been avoided.

results.title: The Invasion (1775-1975)
results.creator_credit: Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1975, as a Bicentennial special, one thousand American history buffs put on period uniforms and re-enacted the 1775 march of General Benedict Arnold’s troops into Quebec. This short film takes a page of our history which has, perhaps, not yet been completely written. Voice and narration by Griffith Brewer.

results.title: Return of Milton Whitty
results.creator_credit: Don Haldane, Peter Alford, Lee Gordon, Construction Safety Assoc of Ontario and Westminster Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Industrial Safety”.
A new safety officer in a building construction company meets opposition when he introduces a new safety program. He explains the importance of safety measures. Another in the Milton Whitty Safety series in which he has a new safety problem. A short-sighted foreman who thinks he knows all the answers. He does, except for one. And that is how to prevent accidents. Only when tragedy strikes does he realise that “an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure”.

results.title: The Crystal space/time ship
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Infinity series”.
Using computer generated graphics and astrophotography, this virtually wordless video, explores the wonders of the universe, beginning at Mercury and journeying ever outwards into the outermost reaches of space/time.
